DataElement.preferredName: Ovarian Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Stage group determined from information on the tumor (T), regional node (N) and metastases (M) and by grouping cases with similar prognosis for ovarian carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms. --2002_An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms. --2002

Concepts.longName: Ovarian Carcinoma
Concepts.definition: A malignant neoplasm originating from the surface ovarian epithelium.  It accounts for the greatest number of deaths from malignancies of the female genital tract and is the fifth leading cause of cancer fatalities in women.  It is predominantly a disease of older white women of northern European extraction, but it is seen in all ages and ethnic groups.  Adenocarcinomas constitute the vast majority of ovarian carcinomas.  The pattern of metastatic spread in ovarian carcinoma is similar regardless of the microscopic type.  The most common sites of involvement are the contralateral ovary, peritoneal cavity, para-aortic and pelvic lymph nodes, and liver.  Lung and pleura are the most common sites of extra-abdominal spread.  The primary form of therapy is surgical.  The overall prognosis of ovarian carcinoma remains poor, a direct result of its rapid growth rate and the lack of early symptoms.

Property.preferredDefinition: Stage Grouping; an assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage. (caDSR)

Concepts.longName: Stage Grouping
Concepts.definition: An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.origin: AJCC Based:Staging Criteria Based on American Joint Committee on Cancer System
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Ovarian Cancer and Primary Peritoneal Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Group Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of ovarian cancer or primary peritoneal carcinoma, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Ovarian cancer and primary peritoneal carcinoma are surgically/pathologically staged malignancies. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0. T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage II Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage II includes: T2, N0, M0.  T2: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with pelvic extension and/or implants.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIA includes: T2a, N0, M0. T2a: Extension and/or implants on uterus and/or tube(s). No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIA Ovarian Cancer AJCC V6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIA includes: T2a, N0, M0.  T2a: Extension and/or implants on uterus and/or tube(s). No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIB includes: T2b N0, M0. T2b: Extension and/or implants on other pelvic tissues. No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIB Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIB includes: T2b N0, M0.  T2b: Extension and/or implants on other pelvic tissues.  No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIC includes: T2c, N0, M0. T2c: Pelvic extension and/or implants (T2a or T2b) with malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washing. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIC Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIC includes: T2c, N0, M0.  T2c: Pelvic extension and/or implants (T2a or T2b) with malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washing.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0. T3: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage III Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage III includes: T3, N0, M0.  T3: Tumor involves one or both ovaries with microscopically confirmed peritoneal metastasis outside pelvis.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIIA includes: T3a, N0, M0. T3a: Microscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond pelvis (no macroscopic tumor). N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIIA Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIIA includes: T3a, N0, M0.  T3a: Microscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond pelvis (no macroscopic tumor). N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIIB includes: T3b, N0, M0. T3b: Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond pelvis 2 cm or less in greatest dimension. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIIB Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIIB includes: T3b, N0, M0.  T3b: Macroscopic peritoneal metastasis beyond pelvis 2 cm or less in greatest dimension. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IIIC includes: (T3c, N0, M0); (Any T, N1, M0). T3c: Peritoneal metastasis beyond pelvis more than 2cm in greatest dimension and/or regional lymph node metastasis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. N1: Regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IIIC Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IIIC includes: (T3c, N0, M0); (Any T, N1, M0). T3c: Peritoneal metastasis beyond pelvis more than 2cm in greatest dimension and/or regional lymph node metastasis. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  N1: Regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1. M1: Distant metastasis (excludes peritoneal metastasis). (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IV Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IV includes: Any T, Any N, M1.  M1: Distant metastasis (excludes peritoneal metastasis). (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IB includes: T1b, N0, M0. T1b: Tumor limited to both ovaries; capsules intact, no tumor on ovarian surface. No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IB Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IB includes: T1b, N0, M0. T1b: Tumor limited to both ovaries; capsules intact, no tumor on ovarian surface.  No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0. T1: Tumor limited to ovaries (one or both). N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage I Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage I includes: T1, N0, M0. T1: Tumor limited to ovaries (one or both).  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis.  (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IA includes: T1a, N0, M0. T1a: Tumor limited to one ovary; capsule intact, no tumor on ovarian surface. No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IA Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IA includes: T1a, N0, M0.  T1a: Tumor limited to one ovary; capsule intact, no tumor on ovarian surface.  No malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage IC includes: T1c, N0, M0. T1c: Tumor limited to one or both ovaries with any of the following: capsule ruptured, tumor on ovarian surface, malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

Concepts.longName: Stage IC Ovarian Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage IC includes: T1c, N0, M0. T1c: Tumor limited to one or both ovaries with any of the following: capsule ruptured, tumor on ovarian surface, malignant cells in ascites or peritoneal washings.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A finding indicating that the extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

Concepts.longName: Stage Unknown
Concepts.definition: The extent of organ/tissue involvement by a malignant neoplasm is not reported or not assessed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

Ovarian cancer and primary peritoneal carcinoma are surgically/pathologically staged malignancies. (from AJCC 7th Ed.):A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.longName: Ovarian Cancer and Primary Peritoneal Carcinoma TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: A finding about one or more characteristics of ovarian cancer or primary peritoneal carcinoma, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Ovarian cancer and primary peritoneal carcinoma are surgically/pathologically staged malignancies. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: American Joint Committee on Cancer
Concepts.definition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.

Concepts.longName: Stage Grouping
Concepts.definition: An assessment based on the combined evaluation of the patient's T stage, M stage, and N stage, as well as prognostic parameters for specific cancers.

Concepts.longName: Neoplasm Stage
Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.
